0-steno-theory/25-dealing-with-test-anxi.title: Dealing with Test Anxiety
0-steno-theory/25-dealing-with-test-anxi.description:
If you're experiencing test anxiety, you're far from alone. I had horrible test anxiety – it was to the point that my hands would be shaking uncontrollably halfway through a test and I'd have to stop writing entirely to just breathe. I've compiled some of the best tips I've come across, and I hope you find them helpful:
Learn your theory well enough to speed build with it Be honest with yourself and identify gaps in your theory early on Practice at speeds higher than you're testing at to build confidence
Maintain good posture with your elbows tucked into your waist and your steno machine low enough so that your wrists are stabilized on your thighs
Listen to audio that's faster than the speed you'll be testing at right before the exam Just listen and imagine how you would write the faster audio, don't actually write anything
The test will seem manageable in comparison Have a consistent pre-test routine that includes some exercise to burn off adrenaline
Find your inner zen during the test Remember to breathe - deep breathing/box breathing will slow down your heartrate and ground you Breathe in on "ready," and out on "begin" Don't look at your writer - your focus will be pulled away from what you need to write now to what you've already written/failed to write (and any errors you've made) Distract yourself just enough during the test so that the words flow through your fingers effortlessly Suck on a hard candy or chew gum
Close your eyes and think of something that brings you peace and joy (a colour; a place; a friend, family member, or pet; or a memory) Accept and embrace the nerves There will probably be some nervousness (and its unfortunate symptoms) no matter what you do, so embrace it
Some of the best public speakers and musicians deal with performance/test anxiety; there's no need to feel embarrassed or ashamed Write something for every word, even if it's gibberish You can't edit or guess at what you meant to write if there's nothing written Always transcribe! More often than not, we think we did worse than we actually did Tell yourself you got this It's nothing you haven't done in practice
Remember that you're a steno star ⭐

2-medical-terminology/2-body-organizatio.title: Body Organization
2-medical-terminology/2-body-organizatio.description:
Confined spaces within the body that contain internal organs 2 major cavities which are further subdivided: Dorsal cavity: posterior (back) surface of the body Cranial cavity: contains the brain Spinal cavity: contains the spinal cord (spinal canal) Ventral cavity: anterior (front) surface of the body Thoracic cavity: contains the heart & lungs Abdominal cavity: contains the stomach, liver, kidneys, small intestines, & large intestine Pelvic cavity: contains the urinary bladder, parts of the intestine, & some reproductive organs Abdominopelvic cavity: refers to both the abdominal and pelvic cavities Diaphragm: major respiratory muscle used for breathing that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities
Helps to identify accurate directional medical terms Standing straight Arms at side Head forward Palms forward Feet forward
The midline An imaginary line drawn down the center of the body from the top of the head to the feet superior | cranial above; toward the head Example: head is superior to the neck inferior | caudal below; toward the lower end of the body or tail Example: neck is inferior to the head anterior | ventral front surface of the body Example: thoracic cavity is anterior to the spinal cavity posterior | dorsal back surface of the body Example: spinal cavity is posterior to the thoracic cavity medial toward the midline Example: big toe is medial to the small toe lateral away from the midline Example: small toe is lateral to the big toe proximal nearest from the point of attachment to the trunk/point of origin Example: stomach is proximal to the intestines distal farthest from the point of attachment to the trunk/point of origin Example: intestines are distal to the stomach; stomach is distal to the throat superficial near the surface of the body deep away from the surface of the body supine lying on the back, face up (palms facing up) prone lying on the abdomen, face down (palms facing down) plantar sole of the foot dorsum upper portion of the foot Plane: an exposed flat surface of the body

2-medical-terminology/3-skeletal-system..title: Skeletal System
2-medical-terminology/3-skeletal-system..description:
Protection and support of internal organs Movement (act as rigid levers for muscles to pull on) Storage area for calcium and phosphorus Blood cell production in the bone marrow 3 types of bone cells: Osteoblasts: create new bone cells Osteocytes: have limited life span; form bone tissue Osteoclasts: break down bone tissue to release minerals for reabsorption Ossification: process of bone formation Remodelling: breakdown and renewal of bone Axial skeleton Skull Vertebral column (spine) Protects the spinal cord Each bone = vertebra Vertebrae named by location and numbered: 7 cervical vertebrae (C1-C7) 12 thoracic vertebrae (T1-T12) 5 lumbar vertebrae (L-1-L5) sacrum (5 fused bones) coccyx (4 fused bones; tailbone) Separated by intervertebral discs (pads of cartilage that act as shock absorbers) Thoracic cage (chest) 12 ribs total (1-7 true, 8- 10 false, 11-12 floating) Costal cartilage connects ribs together and to sternum (excluding for floating ribs) Sternum (breast bone) Hyoid bone (in the throat) Appendicular skeleton Pectoral girdle Connects arms to the thoracic cage Protects the heart and lungs Pelvic girdle Connects legs to the axial skeleton Protects the pelvic organs Sacroiliac joint: the circle formed by the right & left hip bones (ilia) joining with the sacrum Limbs (arms & legs) How to remember the number of vertebrae in each segment Breakfast at 7 (cervical) Lunch at 12 (thoracic) Supper at 5 (lumbar)



A place where two bones come together Named after bones that form a union Naming a joint The joint between the radius and the carpal (wrist) bones is the radiocarpal joint Suture: immovable joint in skull Synovial fluid is produced by the synovial membrane Synovial membrane + articular cartilage = movement
Wear & tear Osteoarthritis: degeneration of the articular cartilage Rheumatoid arthritis: autoimmune disease which first attacks the joints Osteoporosis: decreased bone density Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction TMJ is the hinge that connects the jawbone to the temporal bone Symptoms: pain/tenderness in/around the ear; problems opening/closing the mouth; and a clicking, popping sound when chewing Cancers Chondrosarcoma: cancer originating in the cartilage Osteosarcoma: cancer originating in the bone Fractures A break or crack in a bone Caused by injury or disease Types of fractures: Pathological fractures: bone breaks because it's weak from disease Closed fracture (simple fracture): bone breaks but doesn't pierce the skin Open fracture (compound fracture): bone breaks and pierces the skin Comminuted fracture: bone breaks and splinters into fragments Colles' fracture: fracture of the distal radius near the wrist Greenstick fracture: bone partially breaks on one side but only bends on the other Treatment types for fractures: Reduction: place the bones back together Open reduction: cut the skin to place the bones back together Closed reduction: manually realign bones without cutting skin (x-ray after to check for proper alignment) Immobilization: place a cast/splint over the broken bone to prevent movement

2-medical-terminology/4-muscular-system..title: Muscular System
2-medical-terminology/4-muscular-system..description:
Voluntary muscle: under conscious control
Involuntary muscle: not under conscious control
3 types of muscle tissue: Visceral Located in walls of internal organs
Under involuntary control Cardiac Located in heart
Under involuntary control Skeletal Located on top of bone
Under voluntary control Ligaments attach bone to bone
Tendons attach muscle to bone All skeletal muscles are connected to 2 bones Muscles can only contract & relax; they work in pairs to accomplish a dual action Flexion: bending a limb
Extension: straightening a limb
Hyperextension: overextending joint beyond anatomical position
Adduction: move toward midline
Abduction: move away from midline
Supination: turn palm forward
Pronation: turn palm backward
Eversion: move sole of foot outward away from midline
Inversion: move sole of foot inward toward midline
Dorsiflexion: bend foot upward
Plantar flexion: bend foot downward Carpal tunnel syndrome Tendons and ligaments in the small passageway in the wrist become inflamed when overused, which puts pressure on the median nerve
Symptoms: numbness, pain, tingling, and weakness Muscular dystrophy (MD) Degeneration of muscle tissue
Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is most common
Symptoms: muscular weakness; and loss of mobility, speech, and breathing Strain (pulled muscle) The tearing, twisting, overstretching, or overextension of muscles and tendons
Treatment: RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation) Sprain Stretching of tearing of ligaments
Symptoms: swelling, inflammation, and bruising Rotator cuff tendinitis Inflammation of the rotator cuff (group of tendons that hold the shoulder joint in place)
Major cause: injury and degeneration Fibromyalgia syndrome Pain in fibrous tissues (muscles, tendons, and ligaments)
Associated with chronic fatigue syndrome
Symptoms: deep muscular aching; throbbing, burning, stabbing pain; and fatigue
Treatment: muscle relaxants, trigger point injections, physiotherapy, and acupuncture

2-medical-terminology/5-cardiovascular-s.title: Cardiovascular System
2-medical-terminology/5-cardiovascular-s.description:
Delivers oxygen and nutrients to the body's cells Carries away carbon dioxide and waste products Blood vessels: fuel line and transportation system Veins: carry blood toward the heart (deoxygenated) Arteries: carry blood away from the hear (oxygenated) Capillaries: transfer oxygen to cells & carbon dioxide from cells Heart: the most powerful muscle in the body 4 chambers of the heart: Right atrium Right ventricle Left atrium Left ventricle Septum: wall dividing the right and left sections of the heart Heart valves: Atrioventricular valves: separate the atria from the ventricles; allow blood to flow only one way (atrium to ventricle) Tricuspid valve (right side) Mitral valve (bicuspid valve; left side) Semilunar valves: allow blood to flow only from the ventricle to the arteries Pulmonary valve (right side) Aortic valve (left side) How to remember the chambers and valves of the heart "TRy PULling My Aorta" tricuspid, pulmonary, mitral, aortic "TRy doing the right thing" tricuspid valve on the right side The heart's electrical system Sinoatrial node (SA node): the heart's natural pacemaker Causes walls of the atria to contract and force blood into the ventricles Electrocardiogram (ECG): a record of the electrical activity of the heart Systolic pressure when the ventricles contract to pump blood out the the heart Diastolic pressure: when the ventricles relax Sphygmomanometer: a device used to measure blood pressure Hypertension: high blood pressure Hypotension: low blood pressure Pulse: movement of the arteries relaxing and contracting in unison with the heartbeat High vs. low blood pressure 130/80 = high blood pressure 130 = systolic pressure; 80 = diastolic pressure 90/60 = low blood pressure 90 = systolic pressure; 60 = diastolic pressure Beginning of systole Tricuspid and mitral valves close End of systole/beginning of diastole Aortic and pulmonary valves close
Cerebrovascular accident (CVA; stroke) Blood stops flowing to the brain Brain cells are damaged due to deprivation of oxygen and nutrients Aneurysm Abnormal swelling in the wall of the artery A ruptured aneurysm is when the wall of the artery bursts and causes hemorrhage Results in stroke, brain damage, coma, and death Arrythmia An irregular or abnormal heart rhythm Coronary artery disease Caused by plaques in the coronary arteries (build-up of fat and cholesterol deposits) Treatment: coronary artery bypass surgery (surgical repair of a narrowed blood vessel) Balloon angioplasty pushes plaque against the wall A stent (wire-mesh tube) is inserted to keep the artery open Cardiac arrest The heart stops pumping blood Congestive heart failure The heart fails to pump blood effectively through the heart Murmur Whooshing extra heart sound Myocardial infarction (heart attack) Death of the heart muscle Primary symptom: chest pain in males, shoulder/back pain in females Treatment: coronary artery bypass surgery A section of blood vessel from the leg/chest is implanted into the heart to reroute the blood around an obstruction

2-medical-terminology/6-obstetrics.html.title: Obstetrics
2-medical-terminology/6-obstetrics.html.description: Gynecology: medical-surgical specialty dealing with female reproductive system in non-pregnant state Obstetrics: medical-surgical specialty dealing with female reproductive system in pregnant state OB/GYN: combination of gynecology & obstetrics Gravida: pregnant Primigravida: woman who has been pregnant once Multigravida: woman who has been pregnant more than once Para: having given birth (regardless of whether stillbirth) Gravidity and parity Gravida 1, para 1 = woman who has been pregnant once & has given birth once Gravida 3, para 2 = woman who has been pregnant 3 times & has given birth twice Gestation period: length of pregnancy (about 40 weeks) For the first 8 weeks following conception, the baby is called an embryo After 8 week of pregnancy, the baby is called a fetus Placenta: organ that forms in the womb during pregnancy Allows for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and the baby Secretes the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) at the start of pregnancy (detected by pregnancy tests) Stimulates the release of estrogen and progesterone Made of chorion (outer layer) and amnion (inner layer) Umbilical cord: lifeline between the mother and baby Amniotic sac: fluid-filled sac that protects the fetus Hormones secreted by the baby trigger labor Pull: the uterus contracts to dilate and pull the cervix over the baby's head The hormone oxytocin controls the contractions The amniotic sac opens ("water breaks") during labor Push: the uterus pushes the baby down the birth canal Pushing usually slows down as the baby's head crowns (emerges) Shape-shift: the mother and baby accommodate to each other's shape Turn: the baby spontaneously turns to allow delivery of the shoulders Breech delivery: the baby is turned around, buttocks first; must c-section Slide: the baby & placenta slide out The umbilical cord gradually stops pulsing and can be safely cut a few minutes after delivery Shrink: the uterus shrinks down to prevent blood loss Apgar score: a rating to evaluate a newborn's health on a 2-point scale A = activity/muscle tone P = pulse G = grimace/reflex A = appearance/skin color R = respiration The uterus gradually returns to its pre-pregnancy size Mammary glands are stimulated to lactate (produce milk) Lasts 6-8 weeks Ectopic pregnancy Embryo implants outside the uterus (usually in fallopian tube) The pregnancy is not viable Hyperemesis gravidarum Extreme morning sickness Mother in danger of dehydration Possible causes: rising blood levels of HCG Treatment: IV fluids, anti-nausea meds, and avoiding triggers Gestational diabetes High blood sugar during pregnancy Goes back to normal after birth Manage with insulin Baby will not be born with diabetes; increases the risk of an extremely large baby Pregnancy-induced hypertension (pre-eclampsia) Severe high blood pressure and swelling of hands, face, & feet Cause: retention of toxins in mother's system Can lead to convulsions in mother and problems for baby if untreated Premature birth A birth that takes place prior to 37 weeks' gestation Babies may have low birth weight & jaundice and may spend time in the NICU Shoulder Dystocia Stuck shoulders Baby fails to rotate to allow shoulders to ease out or baby is just too large for the mother's pelvis and gets stuck Can cause excessive tearing of mother's tissues & bleeding, injury to baby's shoulder and brain damage (due to lack of oxygen) Placenta previa The placenta is abnormally positioned so that is covers the cervix Blocks baby's exit from the womb Requires surgical delivery of baby Meconium aspiration syndrome Meconium: baby's first feces If meconium is passed in utero and the baby breathes it in during delivery, it can cause breathing issues for the baby Fetal distress Baby's heart rate becomes erratic or slows down Amniocentesis A needle is used to withdraw a sample of amniotic fluid from around the fetus Fluid is sent for genetic testing Continuous fetal monitoring If mother is anesthetized, she cannot cannot provide feedback about the progress of her labor or the baby’s condition An electronic fetal monitor is strapped to the mother's abdomen Electrodes may also be screwed into the baby's scalp Assisted delivery Forceps or a vacuum are applied to the baby’s head The baby is manually pulled out of the birth canal Episiotomy The mother's perineum is cut Obstetricians do this in complicated births (fetal distress, breech, shoulder dystocia, excessively large baby) and c-sections Obstetricians also used to (and some still do) this routinely to “prevent tearing” – new research shows natural tears heal better The incision must be surgically repaired Cesarean section Surgical delivery of baby The "husband stitch" A medically unnecessary and harmful surgical procedure in which one/more additional sutures than necessary are used to repair a woman's perineum after being torn during childbirth Its purpose was to tighten the opening of the vagina for the pleasure of the woman's partner during intercourse It can cause a lifetime of pain and is not an approved medical procedure It is considered malpractice without the woman's consent in Canada

2-medical-terminology/7-basic-word-struc.title: Basic Word Structure
2-medical-terminology/7-basic-word-struc.description:
Medical terminology describes: parts of the body locations of the body bodily functions surgical/clinical procedures diseases measurements, medical instruments, etc. Term analysis: an organized approach to learning medical terms Medical terms are made up of 3 word elements: 11 Roots: the main part of the word; often refers to a body part
13 Prefixes: the first part of the word that makes it more specific
12 Suffixes: the end of the word Not all words have all 3 word elements Word with all 3 elements Hypothyroidism Prefix: hypo- (low/deficient) Root: thryroid/o (thyroid gland) Suffix: -ism (condition) Meaning: condition where someone has a deficient thyroid gland Word with no root Aphasia Prefix: a- (without or not) Root: n/a Suffix: -phasia (speech) Meaning: difficulty with language/speech Word with no prefix Cardiology Prefix: n/a Root: cardi/o (heart) Suffix: -ology (study of) Meaning: study of the heart Word with 2 roots Cardiomyopathy Prefix: n/a Root 1: cardi/o Root 2: my/o Suffix: -pathy (disease) Meaning: disease of the heart muscle Combining form: a root + a combining vowel Combining vowel: usually "o," but sometimes "i" (as in pelv/i) or "e" Purpose is to aid in pronunciation when: Root + root Cardiomyopathy or osteoarthritis Root + suffix when the suffix begins with a consonant Cardiology (cardi/o + -logy) Analyze the meaning of a medical term starting with the suffix

3-judicial-system/1-types-of-law.html.title: Types of Law
3-judicial-system/1-types-of-law.html.description: A set of rules created by a society that governs the conduct of its members, is recognized and enforced by the government, and includes a punishment if broken The rule of law: No one is above the law; everyone is subject to the law and treated equally The court system settles disputes; we don't take matters into our own hands Tells you what the rules are Public law deals with issues that affect society as a whole Private law deals with issues that affect private individuals or organizations Tells you how to apply or enforce those rules. Substantive vs. procedural Substantive: You are charged with theft Procedural: Police must have reasonable grounds to search and arrest you Police must inform you of your legal rights and give you a chance to contact counsel Police must file a charge specifying what you are accused of Police must release you or bring you before a judge or justice of the peace in order to speak to bail The trial must occur within a reasonable timeframe The trial must adhere to certain procedures and strict rules of evidence

3-judicial-system/6-guilty-plea-and-sent.title: Guilty Plea and Sentencing Procedure
3-judicial-system/6-guilty-plea-and-sent.description: Determination of guilt Determination of punishment Denunciation To publicly condemn the unlawful conduct Deterrence - General - discourage the general public from committing the same/similar offence in the future - Specific - discourage the accused from committing the same/similar offence in the future Other purposes: Separate offenders from society if necessary Rehabilitate offenders Provide reparations for harm done Promote a sense of responsibility in offenders to victims and their community A sentence must be proportionate to the gravity of the offence and the degree of responsibility of the offender The judge must attempt to impose a penalty which balances the competing interests of both the guilty party and society Sentence should be increased/reduced to account for relevant aggravating/mitigating circumstances relating to the offence/offender Statutory aggravating factors: Hate crime Domestic violence Victim under 18 Abused position of trust/authority Gang/criminal organization Terrorism Similar sentences for similar offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances Combined sentence should not be unduly long or harsh All available sanctions other than imprisonment that are reasonable in the circumstances should be considered (particularly indigenous offenders) Sentencing is an individualized process within the framework of the Criminal Code and precedent A judge/justice should craft a sentence that embraces traditional indigenous sentencing principles where possible The more serious the offence, the less emphasis placed on these considerations R. v. Gladue, [1999] 1 SCR 688 R. v. Ipeelee, [2012] 1 SCR 433 Sentencing hearing Can be quick and happen right after verdict OR adjourned to a later time/date After submissions of counsel, there are also be: Order from the judge for a presentence report to help them understand the individual circumstances of the offender/offence Victim impact statements Viva voce evidence Exhibits Imprisonment/custodial sentence One of the most severe sentences Sentencing judge is required to use less restrictive sanctions if possible Provincial institution: for sentences < 2 years Federal institution: for sentences > 2 years Imprisonment for life First-degree murder = automatic life - no eligibility for 25 years Second-degree murder = automatic life - no eligibility for 10-25 years (jury may make recommendation for parole ineligibility period) Other offences = no edibility for parole for 7 years Intermittent sentence: term of imprisonment typically served on weekends Conditional sentence (house arrest): option for sentences 2 years or less; served in the community Concurrent sentences: sentences imposed for separate crimes are served at the same time Consecutive sentences: sentences imposed for separate crimes are served one after the other Fine Probation Discharge Dangerous offender Long-term offender Conditional release of a prisoner before they've served their full custodial sentence To promote successful reintegration into society Remainder of sentence served in the community under supervision When a prisoner is eligible for release, the Parole Board of Canada will assess the risk posed and make a decision on whether to grant parole Temporary release Day parole Full parole Statutory release If parole is breached = fine is imposed May be imposed for any offence which doesn't have a minimum term of imprisonment If the accused doesn't have the money on hand, they can Ask for time to pay OR work off the fine under the fine option program Deemed days: a prescribed number of days the accused will spend in jail if they don't pay the fine (proportionate to the amount of the fine) Where an accused pleads guilty or is found guilty of an offence, the judge may choose to suspend the passing of sentence for a period of time Conviction entered Accused is placed on probation for a period of time and required to abide by conditions If probation order is followed successfully, no further punishment If probation order is breached Brought back to court and sentenced on the original charge and/or charged with criminal offence of breach of probation Community Service Work done in and for the benefit of the community Done to pay off a monetary fine or as a term of probation Restitution Payment made by the accused to cover actual expenses resulting from the commission of the offence to the victim (broken window, slashed tire...) Where an accused pleads guilty or is found guilty of an offence, the judge may grant a discharge instead of entering a conviction Must be in the best interests of the accused and not contrary to public interest 2 types of discharge: Absolute discharge Deemed not to have been convicted No criminal record Conditional discharge Accused is placed on probation for a period of time and required to abide by conditions If probation order is followed successfully, the discharge becomes absolute If probation order is breached Brought back to court and sentenced on the original charge and/or charged with criminal offence of breach of probation Reminder about criminal records If accused is given a discharge = no criminal record If accused is given a suspended sentence = they have a criminal record Dangerous, violent, and sexual predators who are likely to reoffend in the future Crown can make an application after conviction has been entered, and there would follow a lengthy sentencing hearing with viva voce evidence including psychological evidence If Crown is successful = accused is given an indeterminate term of imprisonment Remain in custody indefinitely Until the risk to reoffend no longer exists Used where an individual doesn't meet the criteria for a DO designation but has been convicted of a serious personal injury offence and is considered likely to re-offend If declared a LO, the accused will be sentenced to a specified term of incarceration Upon release, accused will be subject to a supervision order in the community for a max of 10 years Victim fine surcharge Monetary penalty paid by accused in addition to any other sentence DNA order Mandatory for primary designated offences Discretionary for secondary designated offences Firearms and weapons prohibition Sometimes mandatory Sex Offenders Information Registry (SOIRA) order Sometimes mandatory Canvassing Section 606(1.1) Accused is entering the guilty plea voluntarily, understands the consequences of pleading guilty, and understands that the Court is not bound by any argument made by counsel Joint submission Joint recommendation for sentence by Crown and defence The judge is not bound to accept a joint submission Statement by accused Accused may address the Court before sentence is imposed If the accused pleads guilty, there is no need for a trial Disputes the facts in a material way? Offers a defence? Doesn't acknowledge the requirements of Section 606(1.1)? Appears to be of unsound mind? Then... Guilty plea is not struck Not guilty plea is entered on their behalf Matter is set down for trial in front of a different judge/justice An offence whose elements are encompassed by a greater offence You can't commit the greater offence without also committing the lesser included offence(s) Some lesser included offences Theft + assault = robbery Assault + possession of a weapon = assault with a weapon Break and enter + theft = break and enter and commit theft

3-judicial-system/7-presentation-of-evid.title: Presentation of Evidence
3-judicial-system/7-presentation-of-evid.description: The accused is presumed innocent Crown has the burden of proof So... Crown must present their case first Call witnesses to testify Enter exhibits Accused has the option to call a case (they don't have to prove anything) Formal commitment to tell the truth should be binding upon one's conscience Oath: includes a statement to a high power based upon one's religion Affirmation: does not include a religious statement Cross-examination is limited to issues arising from examination-in-chief (direct examination) Re-examination is limited to issues arising from cross-examination Re-cross-examination is limited to issues arising from re-examination Leading question: a question which suggests the answer Only permitted in cross-examination/re-cross examination A leading question Q What color was the vehicle? vs. Q Was the vehicle a black Ford SUV? 3-judicial-system/8-preliminary-inquiry-.title: Preliminary Inquiry Procedure
3-judicial-system/8-preliminary-inquiry-.description: Pretrial hearings held in Provincial Court For offences proceeding by Indictment where the max penalty is 14 years or more To determine if there is sufficient evidence for the case to proceed to trial in the Court of King's Bench The accused may waive the preliminary inquiry with consent of the Crown The accused will be ordered to stand trial without the need for further evidence Direct indictment: allows Crown to bypass preliminary inquiry and proceed straight to trial Only in rare and exceptional circumstances because it takes away the accused's right to a preliminary inquiry Extremely long/complex cases To protect ongoing police investigations May cause significant harm to a witness (psychological or physical) A preliminary was commenced but not concluded There is deliberate delay of proceedings Requires written consent of the Attorney General This case established rules about disclosure as it relates to a fair trial Full disclosure: Crown must share all evidence (even evidence that could help defence and harm their own case) in a timely manner so as to let defence prepare for trial Before this, preliminary inquiries were held so that defence could learn about the Crown's case Do you already have enough disclosure? Do you want evidence "on the record"? Will a preliminary inquiry help the defense understand the evidence and witnesses better for trial? Could a preliminary inquiry help the Crown find and fix weaknesses in their case? Could the accused face new charges arising out of the evidence? Can a preliminary inquiry help to settle the case? Can the client afford both a preliminary inquiry and a trial? Crown only needs to establish a prima facie case There must be some evidence on each of the essential elements of the crime Any doubt in the mind of the Provincial Court judge during a preliminary inquiry is resolved in favour of the Crown How sufficient evidence works IF the evidence called by the Crown is believed, COULD the accused be found guilty? Yes - accused is ordered to stand trial No - accused is discharged All prospective witnesses are excluded from the courtroom until their testimony is done at trial This is done before the commencement of a trial or preliminary inquiry On the motion of one of the parties or the Court (the judge) Evidence taken at a preliminary inquiry shall not be published or broadcast or transmitted in any way until: The accused is discharged or preliminary or The trial in Court of King's Bench has ended Reasons for ban: Reading/watching media coverage may color a witness's testimony Media coverage could influence/bias potential jurors What if a witness is in the courtroom when they should have been excluded? They may still testify BUT the judge may place less weight on their evidence Submissions made by counsel are not evidence To help the trier of fact understand the evidence to be presented Outlines the facts that they intend to prove Summarizes the theory of their case To persuade the trier of fact to decide in your favor Emphasizes evidence favorable to their case Emphasizes weaknesses in the other party's case Suggests how the law should be applied to the evidence The judge may order the accused to stand trial on a lesser included charge or additional charges arising from the evidence Criminal Code Section 541(2) Do you wish to say anything in answer to these charges or to any other charges which might have arisen from the evidence led by the prosecution? You are not obliged to say anything, but whatever you do say may be given in evidence against you at your trial. You should not make any confession or admission of guilt because of any promise or threat made to you, but if you do make any statement, it may be given in evidence against you at your trial in spite of the promise or threat. Denoted with a P Prelim exhibits Full exhibit: EXHIBIT P-1 - Autopsy Exhibit for identification: EXHIBIT P-A FOR IDENTIFICATION - Autopsy Help counsel prepare for trial Refresh a witness's recollection Impeach a witness at trial ("You said something different before. Were you lying?")

3-judicial-system/9-trial-procedure.html.title: Trial Procedure

3-judicial-system/10-jury-selection.html.description: Charter Section 11(f) Any person charged with an offence has the right... (f) to the benefit of trial by jury where the maximum punishment for the offence is imprisonment for five years or a more severe punishment. When it comes to jury trials, the Charter guarantees: Right to have Duty to serve Verdict must be unanimous If defence can convince just one juror, conviction is barred Jurors can be more subjective and sympathetic Jurors may not fully understand complexities of the law Good defence counsel can influence jurors Jurors can be biased against certain defendants and offences Jurors can be more subjective and sympathetic Jurors may not fully understand complexities of the law Good Crown counsel can influence jurors Jury = judges of the facts Determines what has/hasn't been proven Assesses the credibility of the witnesses and what weight to give their evidence Decides whether the accused is guilty or not guilty Judge = judge of the law Determines what evidence is legally admissible and the jury may hear Instructs the jury on the law and how to apply the law to the facts they find Imposes sentences Instructs prospective jurors to attend for jury selection on a specific date Array: Due to: Poor health Personal/professional hardship Recent jury service The justice may direct a juror called to stand by for reasons of personal hardship or other reasons The accused and Crown are entitled to a jury that: Is unbiased Will approach their duties without fear, favour, or prejudice Will decide the case solely on the evidence they hear and see in the courtroom A fully constituted jury: 12 jurors in criminal trials 6 jurors in civil trials 2 alternate jurors selected Can replace a selected juror prior to the start of trial Excused if not needed Generally used in long trials 1 or 2 additional jurors may be selected Serve on jury May deliberate at the end of trial Standard jury selection From a random array Typically not written by a court reporter Challenge for cause jury selection Voir dire Trial within a trial (in-trial hearing) Determines an issue separate from the ultimate issue (guilt or liability) Counsel applies for this if there's concern that the entire array may be biased Discovers whether prospective jurors have preconceived opinions/influenced by media reports about issues in the trial Written by a court reporter and forms part of the transcript if the case is appealed Transcript notation for a standard jury selection (JURY SELECTED) Some questions they may ask in a challenge for jury selection Have you heard or read about this case before today? Have you discussed this case with anyone? Have you formed any opinion of the case? Do you believe that black men, as a group, are more likely to be violent, generally? Change of venue application A request to have the trial heard in a different judicial district Typically made when there are concerns that the array may be biased

5-writing-realtime/1-introduction-to-cap.description:
What is CART?
CART = Communication Access Realtime Translation
an assistive technology which affords "effective communication access“ for hard of hearing (HOH) consumers
A CART provider uses a steno machine, computer, and realtime software to render instant speech‐to‐text translation on a computer monitor or other display for the benefit of an individual consumer or larger group in a number of settings
Who uses CART?
People with hearing loss who do not sign
People who are late‐deafened or hard‐of‐hearing
Members of the Deaf community
EAL community
Benefits of CART to the consumer
Equal communication access
Independence
Freedom
Confidence
Ability
Flexibility
Role of the CART Provider Prepare Confirm rates and cancellation policy Equipment Location Display Environmental sounds Role Transcripts? Confidentiality Update! Update! Update! Who can be a CART Provider?
Realtime writers Who can write at 220+ words per minute
With at least 97% accuracy
NCRA certification – CRC (used to be CCP)
NCRA certification ‐ CRR More information:
CART Provider's Manual
Guidelines for Professional Practice
What is Broadcast Captioning?
On‐screen display of text for spoken dialogue and environmental sounds
An assistive technology which affords "effective communication access“ for HOH consumers
A captioner uses a steno machine, computer, and captioning software to render instant speech‐to‐text translation to an encoder at a remote location to provide text synchronized with television broadcast audio.
Who watches captions?
People with hearing loss who do not sign
People who are late‐deafened or hard‐of‐hearing
Members of the Deaf community
EAL community
Children (language aide)
Benefits of captioning for the consumer:
Equal communication access for HOH consumers
Increased comprehension and reduced language barriers for EAL consumer
Compensates for poor audio quality, noisy background, or reduced comprehension (accents) for all consumers
Language skills for children and EAL consumers (reading, writing, spelling)
Role of the captioner: Prepare Current events Build build build! Moves captions around the screen Identifies speakers Liaise with station personnel to ensure proper transmission Performs self‐reviews for quality control reports Completes discrepancy reports Update update update! Who can be a captioner?
Realtime writers Who can write at 220+ words per minute
With at least 99% accuracy
With an extensive database
NCRA certification – CRC CRC - Certified Realtime Captioner
Designed for those who either currently work or would like to begin working in the broadcast captioning or CART captioning fields
CRC Certification Process
Attend the CRC Workshop, available as an on‐demand e‐seminar or offered at NCRA's annual convention.
Take the CRC online skills test (literary at 180 wpm) with 96% accuracy.
Take the written knowledge test, which follows the written knowledge test schedule currently in place.
Maintaining Certification
Maintain NCRA membership and earn a minimum of 3.0 CEUs over a three‐year period.

5-writing-realtime/5-fingerspelling.html.title: Fingerspelling
5-writing-realtime/5-fingerspelling.html.description: Fingerspelling involves writing a word one letter at a time using alphabets on your steno writer instead of writing a word with phonetic outlines. When you hear a word that isn't in your dictionary, you will need to spell it out.Sound cumbersome? It certainly can be and often is. The good news is that it is a skill that can be practiced and even perfected, and it can become a valuable tool in your realtime career.While fingerspelling is not a substitute for a solid, conflict-free theory and a good workign set of prefixes, suffixes, and word roots, it is an excellent way to handle the occasional oddball word or name that will will inevitably hear on the job.Once you've determined how you will write your fingerspelling alphabet, it's time to practice it. Just as you needed to drill yourself on shorthand speed, you probably will also need to do the same with your fingerspelling skills. Practice at home with random words picked out of the dictionary; experiment with it while practicing for accuracy.Start with small words and work up to longer ones. Work to achieve a steady rhythm as you spell, rather than frantic, jerky bursts. You'll be surprised how quickly that word can come out, if you don't panic! Try to think of fingerspelling as just another bunch of outlines and jump right in.You already have three alphabets in your personal dictionary. Make entries for the fourth alphabet, lowercase letters with parentheses.

5-writing-realtime/8-brief-it!-and-live-.description:
What does it do?
A realtime feature that suggests conflict-free brief forms for words and phrases as you are writing. When you write three or more steno strokes, Case CAT generates a brief form or reminds you of an existing brief form and displays it in the Brief It dialog pane.For example?
You have written "personal chequing account" twice. Case CAT suggests P*K as a brief, which appears in the Brief It pane on a yellow background. You like the suggestions and begin writing P*K, and it translates as "personal chequing account."You write "joint account" out. Case CAT reminds you that J-KT is a brief in your Personal Dictionary. The reminder appears in the Brief It pane on a green background.How do I do it?
Enabled Brief It during realtime translation:
Press Ctrl t to open the Translate dialog box and press Alt p (Options).
Click the Realtime tab.
In the Realtime Aids section, select Brief It.
In a realtime file, open the Brief It pane by pressing Alt v, e, t (View, Panes, Brief It). When you want to use a suggested brief, simply write the steno.
What does it do?
A realtime feature that automatically offers translation suggestions when an untranslate displays in the transcript. You have the option to ignore, replace, or define the suggestion from the writer during realtime or with a keyboard command.For example?
You misstroke and write SHRAOUR. In the Brief It pane, "sure" is the first and correct suggestion. You write a realtime command from your writer to replace the untranslate.How do I do it?
Enable Live Suggestions during realtime translation:
Press Ctrl t to to open the Translate dialog box and press Alt p (Options).
Click the Realtime tab.
In the Realtime Aids section, select Live Suggestions.
Add the Live Suggestions realtime commands to your Personal Dictionary.
In System Files, open the Realtime Commands Dictionary.
Select each of the {Replace With LS#} and {Define With LS#} entries. Right mouse click and copy to your Personal Dictionary.
In your Personal Dictionary, modify the steno as desired. If you select to display more than three Live Suggestions in your options, create new dictionary entries and LS4 and LS5.
In a realtime file, open the Brief It pane by pressing Alt v, e, t (View, Panes, Brief It).
Write the steno stroke for the {Replace With LS#} or {Define With LS#} command that corresponds to the correct Live Suggestion.Tips and Tricks
At least four translated words or phrases need to be written after the untranslate before a Live Suggestion will be offered.Only one Live Suggestion is offered at a time. The suggestions display until the next untranslate is written.Live Suggestions appear on a light blue background in the Brief It pane.One you select a Live Suggestion, the background color turns gray and the remaining suggestions appear crossed out. To hide suggestions that were not selected, deselect the Rejected option in the Brief It pane filter options.You can also right click a Live Suggestion in the Brief It pane and select Replace with this Suggestion or Define this Suggestion. Double clicking a Live Suggestion will replace the untranslate.Modify Brief It Options
From the All Options dialog box, under Edit Panes, select Brief It.
From the Brief It pane, click the Options icon.
From Manage Jobs, press Alt t, o, e, b (Tools, Options, Edit, Brief It).
From Edit, press Alt t, o, Enter, b (Tools, Options, Pane Options, Brief It).
Show Phonetic Steno
Check this box to have Brief It display steno as it sounds. For example, the suggested brief for "Yoko Ono" would appear as Y*O as opposed to KWR*O.When Show Phonetic Steno is selected, steno in the Cat Scratch Text/Steno section will also display phonetically.Only Suggest 1 Stroke Briefs
Check this box to have Brief It suggest only one-stroke Suggested briefs. By default, Brief It always suggests a one-stroke brief with the asterisk before suggesting a two-stroke brief.Selecting this option also affects Reminder and Personal briefs. For example, you write "neurotoxicity" in four or five strokes. When this option is active, Brief It does not remind you that you have TPHAOUR/TOX in your Personal Dictionary as a two-stroke entry.Write Twice to Define
Brief It, by default, automatically creates a J-Define or a K-Define the first time you use a Suggested brief. Checking this box requires you to consecutively write a brief twice before Brief It creates a J-Define or K-Define. You may want to use this option to try a Suggested brief before making it a definition.For example, Brief It suggests A*BT for "Abbott Labs." If the Write twice to Define option is active, you would need to write A*BT/A*BT to have Case CAT create the global. Once defined, you write A*BT for "Abbott Labs" for the remainder of the job.Define to Case Dictionary
Check this box to place a Suggested brief in the case dictionary once it is written. If the current job is not in a case, then the brief is placed in the job dictionary.Personal/Reminders Only
Check this box to display only Reminder and Personal briefs in the Brief It dialog pane. Suggested briefs are not created.1 Stroke Reminders for 2 Strokes
Check this box to have Brief It offer one-stroke Reminders or Personal briefs when writing two-stroke entries. For example, if you write "I don't" in two strokes and there is a one-stroke version in your Personal Dictionary, Brief It shows the one-stroke brief as a Reminder.Auto Open Brief It
Check this box to automatically display the Brief It dialog pane when starting realtime. By default, this option is selected.Send Used Briefs to Cat Scratch
Check this box to automatically send a Suggested brief you use to the Steno/Text section of the Cat Scratch dialog pane.Steno Include/Exclude
Displays the Brief It Options table where you can modify the Require and Exclude entries.The Require entry contains the steno character or steno combination to be included in every Suggested brief. There is only one Require entry.Exclude entries contain steno characters or steno combinations to exclude from every Suggested brief. You can have multiple Exclude entries.Personal Briefs
Personal Briefs are entries which are created prior to translation and are stored in the Briefs.txt file in the System Files case. A default Briefs.txt file exists for each user.Creating entries in the Briefs.txt file allows you to store words and phrases along with the brief form without placing them in a dictionary. For example, you got some good ideas for briefs from an article in the JCR but you're not certain you want to put them in your Personal Dictionary.Common Words
The CommonWords.txt file contains a list of words the Brief It does not consider when looking for words and phrases for brief suggestions. Is a phrase is written that begins or ends with a word from the CommonWords.txt file, no brief is suggested. For example, by default the word "about" is in the CommonWords.txt file. When a phrase is written that begins or ends with the word "about" and no Reminder or Personal brief exists for the word or phrase, Brief It does not suggest a brief.Allow Briefs with Numbers
Check this box to have Brief It offer suggestions for repeated dollar amounts or addresses.An additional option is available in the Steno Include/Exclude list where a Required for Numbers entry is available. For example if the Required for Numbers entry is EU and you write 23925 several times throughout the transcript, Brief It might suggest 23EU9. (EU is the default steno entry.)Be default, the following number/steno key combinations are excluded in the Brief Include/Exclude Options: #1S, #2K, #3W, #4R, #6-R, #7-B, #8-G, #9-STo prevent any number bar number from being suggested, press Ctrl + i and type # and press Enter.Allow Double First Syllable
Check this box to have Brief It offer the first syllable of the text (single word or phrase) written twice as the suggested brief. For example, the word "fluorescent" is used multiple times in the transcript. You write "fluorescent" in multiple strokes and Brief It suggests TPHROR/TPHROR.When you have both Write Twice to Define and Allow Double First Syllable options selected, if the suggested brief has two identical strokes, Brief It will behave as if "Write Twice to Define" option was not active. In other words, you do not need to write the brief four times to use it. If the brief is one stroke or is multiple (not identical) strokes, briefs will need to be written twice to be used.No Nag List
Check this box to designate words or phrases that should no longer be offered as a suggestion or a reminder. For example, you have the phrase "of the" in your Personal Dictionary, but sometimes you write it in two strokes. You do not want Brief It to remind you of the phrase.From the Brief It pane, right click an entry or highlight multiple entries and then right click. Select Send Text to No Nag List. Alternatively, select No Nag List in Brief It options and type the text portion of the entry.Insert Oops when replacing with a live suggestion
Select to add an <Oops> format symbol (category 10) whenever you select to replace an untranslate with a Live Suggestion. This enables you to scan to Live Suggestion replacements and confirm change. You can also view each instance in the Hotspots pane.Number of Suggestions
Select how many suggestions should be offered in the Brief It pane. Select from 2 to 5 suggestions. The default number of suggestions is 3.Dictionary Defines go to
Select the destination dictionary you want a defined suggestion to go to when using the {Define With LS#} commands. When this option is set to case dictionary and the transcript is not in a case, entries will go to the job dictionary.Show "translated" text as first Live Suggestions
By default, this option is active and Drag/Drop, Suffix Drag, and phonetically translated text will be the first choice in the Live Suggestion list.

5-writing-realtime/9-phonetic-translatio.title: Phonetic Translation
5-writing-realtime/9-phonetic-translatio.description:
What is it?
When active, Case CAT phonetically translates steno outlines when no match is found in any dictionary used for translation. This prevents the display of untranslates on the realtime screen.Put another way:
The Phonetic Table contains steno outlines and phonetic text equivalents. When the Advanced Translate option, Phonetic untranslates display as words is set to No and you select the Phonetic Translation option or use the Toggle Phonetic Mode during realtime, steno outlines normally displayed as untranslates translate phonetically based on the text equivalent entry in the Phonetic Table and Suggested briefs based on your Brief It options.Example
The proceedings include the name Jaymes. If no dictionary entry for the steno SKWRAEUPLZ exists, the steno outline displays as an untranslate. Using the Phonetic Table, each steno combination matches to the text equivalent. The result displays as JAIMZ in the transcript instead of SKWRAEUPLZ, as shown:SKWR  = J
A = A
EU = I
PL  = M
-Z = ZWhen the Advanced Translate option “Phonetic untranslates display as words” is set to Yes, Case CATalyst use a phonetic algorithmic logic to determine the intended pronunciation. The Phonetic Table is not used.How do I do it?
In the Input tab of Translation Options, you can have Phonetic Translation automatically turn on when you start a realtime file.Alternatively, you can add the Toggle Phonetic Mode entry to your personal dictionary and turn it on or off directly from your machine.{Toggle Phonetic Mode} = TOPB/TOPBHow does it work?The phonetic table in System Files contains steno outlines and phonetic text equivalents. Steno outlines translate phonetically based on the text equivalent in the phonetic table./PHROFRP = PlompPhonetic untranslates display as words - Yes/NoSelect Yes to phonetically translate single stroke untranslates during realtime using algorithmic logic to determine the intended pronunciation. Case CATalyst bases the logic on Stenograph Theory and the WinterTree Spell Check, Stedman’s Medical and Black’s Legal wordlists to create a word with the most accurate spelling of the phonetically sounded word. Phonetic translation applies when no dictionary match is found in any dictionary used for translation.

5-writing-realtime/11-realteam.html.title: 11 RealTeam
5-writing-realtime/11-realteam.html.description:
What is it?It's a simultaneous editing feature which allows sharing of text, globals, and audio with one or more scopists or proofreaders while the reporter is writing realtime.For example?A reporter begins a realtime file and invites their scopist to join. The scopist accepts the invitation, and the realtime file opens on their computer. The scopist has access to the audio and can perform all editing functions. Any changes made by the reporter or the scopist are reflected on both systems.What do I need?
RealTeam or Cloud Backup login
Contact information for the scopist or proofreader
Internet connection with or without a local network
Edge for Case CAT Support Plan
How do I do it?
Each participant logs in to RealTeam by selecting RealTeam Ready from the file menu/RealTeam toolbar
The reporter (host) begins a realtime file and invites each participant to the RealTeam session from the Translate dialog box/RealTeam toolbar/File menu
Each participant will hear a "ringing" sound when the invitation is received, and the Case CAT icon will flash on the Windows taskbar. The RealTeam dialog box will display the email address of the host and the path and filename where the transcript will be opened.
Once the invitation is accepted, each participant will immediately receive the entire available text file and audio file. The participants can begin editing the file.
Tips & TricksOpen the Connected Users pane to display the status of each participant.If you are editing right up against the realtime text, the audio playback may stop because there isn't audio available yet. Select Play Audio again after a few seconds.If there is more than one scopist or proofreader working on the same file, one person should be designated as the team's leader and determine who is responsible for editing which portions of the job. It's recommended that each participant leave hidden text or visible notes at stopping or starting points to avoid gaps or duplication of efforts.Additional NotesThe participant's system will adopt the file structure and naming convention as established by the host.Settings such as page/normal view, colors, and panes display are based on the individual user settings.Each participant's name will display on the screen to indicate their cursor location along with their current page number/location. If a participant is editing above the current text on the screen, their cursor (name) displays in the upper left-hand corner of your realtime screen. If their cursor is below the current text on the screen, their cursor displays in the lower left-hand corner of the realtime screen.Double clicking a fellow participant's cursor position will shift your view to their position in the file.

5-writing-realtime/12-caseprep.html.title: 12 CasePrep
5-writing-realtime/12-caseprep.html.description:
What does it do?Enables you to quickly and thoroughly prepare for your next job. Case Prep compares transcripts and other documents against one or more dictionaries to determine which words are and are not in your dictionaries. Case Prep uses this information to
generate a Dictionary Builder List for words and phrases that are not in the selected dictionaries or your Personal Dictionary
generate a Heads Up List of words and phrases that you will want to define and possibly brief.
For example?The RCTT lawsuit is coming to trial, and you expect daily transcript to be ordered. You are going to do some prep work so that your translation is as clean as possible. You have been provided discovery transcripts from colleagues, some on Case CAT and some on a different software. You are also planning to do some internet research about suitable soil types for construction. You run Case Prep and quickly mine the relevant information from all sources. You then create dictionary entries and generate briefs.How do I do it?
Gather your resources. Restore Case Cat transcripts to your user. Text or PDF documents which contain helpful information can be saved anywhere on your computer.
Supported file types are Cat text files (.sgngl), Cat BCS files (.sgcap), ASCIIs (.txt), .PDFs, .PTX, and/or .XMEF
If a colleague on different CAT software provides a file in the RTF/CRE format, import the file into Case Cat.
If you are obtaining information from email or the internet, copy and paste the text into a Case Cat file.
From Manage Jobs, click Tools, Case Prep. Complete the steps as prompted in the wizard.
Tips & TricksYou can print the contents of the Brief It pane by clicking the Printer icon on the Brief It pane.If you want different results (one list containing phrases sorted by and one list containing words and phrases not in the dictionary sorted by words then phrases), you can run Case Prep more than once.A Microsoft Word document can be saved as a plain .TXT file and used with Case Prep.Phrases are generated from transcripts (.sgngl) or caption (.sgcap) files whether there is underlying steno outlines or not. ASCII and PDF files will only generate words, so it may be preferable to paste the contents of an ASCII or PDF into a Case CAT text file.

display options may include computers, monitors, large screens, and mobile devices

What is it?
An alternative to sharing the writer’s screen is Output to CARTView which allows the writer to display the text on a second monitor or screen.
CARTView (local display) is available in the Output To: field in the Translate dialog box. Outputting to CARTView displays a separate window which can display on your computer or you can drag the window to another monitor or computer screen. The CARTView window displays text with no toolbars or menus.
The display may be customized by changing the color of the text, background, font style and size, background transparency, line spacing and the position of the window. You can save the CARTView settings to the Alternate User Settings feature.
Editing changes to the realtime screen are reflected on the CARTView screen. If the CARTView window is displayed on another monitor/computer, you can use editing features that display dialog boxes on the realtime screen without displaying the dialog boxes on the CARTView window. For example, you can use the Power Define feature to easily define from your writing machine or you can have the Brief It pane open in your software.
The Case CATalyst CARTView Settings Icon is available in the Windows System Tray. When selected, the icon displays the CARTView screen settings such as font, transparency, color, etc. The system tray icon makes it easy to control the CARTView settings when you do not have instant access to the CARTView window.
For example, let’s say you are in the back of a large convention room with CARTView displaying on a large screen in the front of the room when you realize you need to change the color or the size of the text to make it more readable. By clicking the Case CATalyst CARTView Settings icon, you will instantly have access to the CARTView settings. No need to go to the front of the room to make adjustments.

A variety of windowing options allow you to view your realtime translation, make corrections to the translation, preview the text that displays on the viewer’s television and organize your story scripts. Additional features include the ability to view your vertical notes, session selections, and the status of the captioning mode.Click (the BCS Captioning button) on the Function Bar or click Function, Broadcast Captioning Suite (or press Alt+u, b).Captioning Options
Caption Translate options are a group of settings that affect how CATalyst BCS translates steno outlines. You set translate options on the Options tab in the Caption Options dialog box prior to starting a session or during a captioning session using the Options feature on the Setup menu. Options settings remain the same until you change them.There are three translate options specific to BCS.Remove Single Empty Paragraph
Suppress the blank line generated when a steno outline with a paragraph style is followed by a stroke defined with a paragraph style at the beginning of the definition.
Replace Q&A With >>
Converts Question and Answer format symbol to chevrons (>>).
Hold Strokes
When active, steno outlines are held before displaying the translated text on the live display. CATalyst BCS holds the steno until it finds the longest dictionary match plus the specified number of additional strokes. Once a longest match is found, BCS re-translates the steno outlines to display the longest match text. If no steno is written for a specified number of seconds, then the translated text or steno on the screen displays regardless of the longest match.
For example, let's say your Longest match plus X strokes option is set to 3 and the Held for X seconds option is set to 2. You write a four-stroke word which is a longest match plus three more strokes. When the longest match plus the additional strokes are written, CATalyst pushes out the translation. If translation isn't done with the longest match, it will hold back the translation for 2 seconds. This creates a “buffer zone” to allow for corrections in the Realtime pane.

6-the-business/4-the-interview.html.title: The Interview
6-the-business/4-the-interview.html.description:
An opportunity for an employer to assess you and your skills against their requirements for the job and the company.
For you to assess if this is where you want to work – the type of work and the company.
Preparing
3R’s: Research, Research, Research Check out the firm website.
Use practical training as an opportunity to assess a firm.
Talk to someone who works there: firm owner, supervisor, court reporter Caution – if you phone or Zoom: Make sure person has time to spend.
Ask specific questions – be prepared.
Don’t try to sell yourself. Prepare your own “interview” questions
Prepare responses to questions Don’t have “canned” or textbook answers 3 P’s: practice, practice, practice
Obtain feedback
Think about how you will dress, present yourself and be remembered
Interview Types
Depends on level of position and size of organization) One-on-one (firm owner / supervisor)
Panel (firm owner, supervisor, and/or court reporter)
One or two-stage
- Could start with a panel and move to one-on-one.
Sparkle and Shine The First 30 Seconds “The first 30 seconds of a job interview are crucial.” – Ollie Stevenson
Based on experiences of real-life people.
“The interviewer makes an immediate overall judgment about you within the first five seconds, and the next 25 seconds are spent checking the chemistry and verifying the initial impression.”
Decisions often made in the first few minutes.
First Impressions
Handling nervousness: breathing exercise, visualization, and positive self-talk
Arrive 10 minutes early
Make an impression on everybody, including the receptionist and other staff
How to Handle Early Moments
Project the image that fits the job you are going after.
Make eye contact, smile, and trust your gut reactions.
Introduce yourself in a courteous manner.
Have a firm handshake. (COVID warning)
Not too eager; not too nervous.
Just be yourself.
Remember: People prefer to do business with those they like.
Dance their dance. If they sit, you sit. If they joke, you smile.
The more research you’ve done on the company before the interview will help your “chemistry” with the Interview.
Within five minutes the interviewers can tell how the interview will go.
Answering Employer's Questions
Make eye contact
Use S.T.A.R. method (Situation, Task, Activities, Result)
Be positive and professional – i.e. do not criticize former employers or staff
DO NOT LIE OR EXAGERRATE
- Body language will generally give you away
Verbal Communication
Speak clearly so that the interviewer can easily hear you.
Use good grammar and appropriate vocabulary and avoid slang. Eg. Yeah, you guys, like, you know, whatever, hey, et cetera. Practice changing bad habits (self-awareness).
Professional tone.
Sound positive – don’t use words like “think” or “guess.”
Non-Verbal Communication
90 percent of what we say comes from body language; 10 percent from what we say.
Positive and relaxed body language
Good posture
Good eye contact, include everyone present
Smile
Open posture; placement of hands
Use natural hand movements; not distracting.
Avoid fidgeting or distracting mannerisms.
Listening and Responding Skills
Listen to the question and do not interrupt.
Ask the interviewer for clarification if needed.
Think about your answer. You do not have to answer immediately after a question is asked. Take your time.
Answer the question briefly, but with enough information to fully answer the question.
Use a conversational tone.
Unassertive words (hesitant, fills interview with doubts): I’ll think about it.
I’ll try.
Maybe
I’m not sure.
Yes, but
I don’t know.
Aggressive words (overbearing):
That was a stupid question.
Who do you think you are?
Well, have I got the job or not?
No sweat.
Disclaimers:
I’m sorry, but…
You may not believe this but…
This may seem silly but…
Would you mind very much if…
Assertive words (confident):
I will or I won’t
I can or I can’t
Yes, no, or I prefer
I would like to find out (indicates your willingness)
I assure you that won’t happen
Show Enthusiasm Do you look like someone who really wants this job?
Convince yourself before convincing an interviewer!
It may be the difference that lands you the job.
If lacking, it is time for reflection and soul-searching.
Supporting Information and Interview-Ending Behaviour
Have questions prepared when asked if you have any questions.
Extra copies of resume and application letter.
List of references and contact information.
Say “thank you” for the interview.

6-the-business/5-taxes,-expense-accounts.description:
If the reporter's relationship with the firm is that of a subcontractor, the reporter must pay their income tax quarterly to CRA When reporters receive income from work, a percentage of that income needs to be set aside for tax purposes, including paying CPP (recommendation: 30%) Taz laws change every year - to make sure reporters are taking advantage of all the tax deductions to them and to avoid the potential of a possible audit, they may want to seek professional help Tax calculator: https://simpletax.ca/calculator?&gclid=EAIaIQobChMIxbObrYTA5wIVj8VkCh3wUgo5EAAYAyABEgLZ_fD_BwE Tax deduction: reduces the amount of income that's subject to tax (e.g., operational court reporting expenses, RRSPs) Tax credit: reduces the amount of tax owing An amount eligible for a tax credit generally creates a federal tax savings based on the lowest tax bracket, 15% A 10,000 tax credit amount will generate $1,500 actual tax credit against taxes owing, which means your tax bill is lower by $1,500 (10,000 x 15%) The calculation is the same no matter the tax bracket (e.g., tuition expenses, donations, student loan interest, medical expenses, Canada child benefit, child care deduction, age) Marginal tax rate: the amount of tax paid on any additional dollar made up to the next tax bracket Average tax rate: percentage of tax paid based on your total taxable income and reflects the total tax you are paying Tax Deductions the reporter doesn't have to claim the deduction in the year they purchased the item some of the deductions reporters generally are allowed include: Anything purchased to help reporters perform their job, including shorthand machine, computer hardware and software. Some items are depreciated over time (shorthand machine) and some can be written off 100% at the time of purchase (software). Depending on the working arrangement with the firm, car expenses including gas and maintenance. A log needs to be kept of business versus personal travel including date, destination, purpose, and number of kilometres driven (see example). Full cost of some utility expenses, including home Internet and phone expenses if used for the job. Partial cost of other utility expenses, including power and heat. Based on a percentage of office space with the rest of the house (see example). Any items purchased to create a home office. Note: Generally, items 3, 4, and 5 can only be claimed if an office is not provided for you at the place you work. How to Claim Care Expenses Example On January 1 the odometer on your vehicle says 10,000 kms. On December 31 the odometer on your vehicle says 30,000 kms. By keeping a log, you determine 5,000 kms. were business related. From this example, you are able to write off 25% of your vehicle expenses. 5,000/20,000=25% Note: There are different rules for a purchased vehicle. Write-Offa Include: - Leasing - Gas - Servicing and Repairs - Insurance - Parts - Licence and Registration fees - Car Washes - Note: Parking is a 100% write-off if done for business purposes. How to Claim Home Expenses Layout Particulars - Apartment is 1,000 square feet - Office is 100 square feet (10 x10) - 100/1,000 means you can write off 10% of the following items: - Rent (get advice) - Gas and electricity - Water - General home repairs not particular to a given room. - You can still write of 100% of the following items: - Internet - Cell phone - Items and repairs for your office only (some of these may be depreciated) Tax rates based on taxable income Canada Tax Brackets for 2023 Alberta Tax Brackets for 2023Tax Rate Example Assumption: Reporter had taxable income of $70,000 working in Alberta. - Federal tax: $7,798 - Provincial tax: $4,149 - CPP Deduction: $7,509 - Total tax to be paid: $19,455 - Net Pay: $50,545 - Average Tax Rate: 18.21% - Marginal Tax Rate: 30.5% Employment Insurance Benefits for the Self-Employed Optional benefit a self-employed person can pay for through a tax deduction. Benefit: Financial support of up to 55% of earnings to maximum of $650 per week (2023). Types of benefits: maternity, parental, sickness, family caregiver for children, compassionate care. Conditions: Be registered in self-employed program for at least 12 months Decreased the amount of time you spend on your business by more than 40% for at least one week. Have earned a minimum amount of net self-employed earnings between January 1 and December 31 of the year before you apply for benefits. How to register: Register online for the program through My Service Canada Account (MSCA) Pay EI premiums You can apply for special benefits 12 months after your confirmed registration date. Estimate of Premiums For 2023, you will pay $1.63 in EI premiums for every $100 earned to a maximum of $1,002.45. (Rate changes annually) Same rate as an employee would pay. NOTE: “Once you receive benefits as a self-employed person, you’ll continue paying premiums for as long as you’re self-employed.” Expense Accounts Arrangements are usually made for reporters to be reimbursed when they have to travel out of town. If the reporter is paying for the expenses out their own pocket (to be reimbursed later), it is best to pay with a credit card. If the reporter happens to lose their receipt, then they will still have a record of the transaction. When reporters do out-of-town work and receive money for meals and/or mileage (e.g., $50 per day for meals and 50 cents a kilometer), they do not have to claim that money as income on their income tax returns. If a reporter does receive money for mileage, they cannot claim that trip as a taxable vehicle expense on their income tax return. GST - Goods and Services Tax When Must GST Registration Take Place? You have 29 days to apply for GST registration from the day that your business exceeds the small supplier threshold amount. If on June 1 your revenues go over $30,000, you have until June 29 to apply for registration. Note: June 1 would be my effective GST registration date, and I will be responsible for collecting GST/HST from that date. How to register for the GST GST registration with the CRA is fairly easy. You can register by phone, online, by mail or drop into your local CRA office. What's the GST Registration Process provides the phone numbers and addresses you need. When you've registered, you'll be assigned a business number. This is a business identification number that you'll use for all your dealings with the CRA.

strokes before providing drafts, if possible Minimum standards Ensure that your writing skills meet the guidelines before distributing drafts, but you can provide them later if needed Ensure integrity 6-the-business/15-role-of-the-court-repo.title: Role of the Court Reporter
6-the-business/15-role-of-the-court-repo.description:
Arrive 30 minutes before the proceeding is set to commence (45-60 minutes if it's videotaped or realtime)
Introduce yourself when you enter the law office
Set up at one end of the table in the discovery room Preferably away from the door
Consider where the electrical outlets and coffee stations are located Introduce yourself and hand out business cards to lawyers Set up your equipment first Make sure everything is working properly Request a style of cause The examining lawyer will have the style of cause Ask for a copy of it or ask if you can take a picture of it It must be written exactly the same way as it's given to you, including capitalization and/or spelling errors
If time permits, quickly scan the style of cause for spellings and to learn about the case you're about to write When working with unfamiliar counsel, ask for their name and who they represent Examples: Unfamiliar Counsel
Court Reporter: Sir, may I have your name, please.
Lawyer: John R. Jones
Court Reporter: And whom do you represent?
Lawyer: I am on for the plaintiff.
Familiar Counsel
Court Reporter: Mr. Jones, who are you representing today?
Lawyer: I am on for the plaintiff, Martin Wilson. Always ask for the witness's full name
*Would you please state your name.
Could you tell me your full name, please. If the witness's name is on the style of cause, you may confirm the spelling.
Is this the correct spelling of your name? If the witness's name is not on the style of cause, ask them to spell their name. If the witness's name is different on the style of cause, confirm the correct spelling. Information Sheet
Keep track of names, spellings, and times of the examination in a notebook or an information sheet.
Some firms will provide you with a template. Billing from expected start time in brackets, not actual start time. Good place to track exhibit numbers.
(10:00)

Martin John Wilson
Examined by Counsel Jones
Setup
Make dictionary entries, speaker IDs, and get yourself ready to write.
Do whatever it takes to feel comfortable before the proceeding starts.
Administering the oath
Administer an oath to the witness prior to examination commencing.
Ask if the witness would like to swear on the Bible or take an affirmation. Counsel will help you to explain if the witness doesn't understand the difference (promise to tell the truth vs. swearing to tell the truth on a Bible)
Make eye contact with the witness while administering the oath.
State the oath in a firm and steady voice.
Oath with a Bible:
Do you solemnly swear the evidence you are about the give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth so help you God?
Affirmation:
Do you solemnly affirm the evidence you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?
People with religious beliefs other than Christian may choose to make an affirmation
People with no religious beliefs may choose to make an affirmation
With an interpreter:
First administer the oath to the interpreter:
Do you solemnly swear to well and truly interpret from the English language to the language and from the language to the English language to the best of your skill and ability so help you God?
Do you solemnly affirm to well and truly interpret from the English language to the language and from the language to the English language to the best of your skill and ability so help you God?
Then administer the oath to the witness through the interpreter.
Example SOC
Main role during the proceeding is to write it verbatim, but other tasks include: Dealing with discussions off the record
Reporter readbacks
Anticipating counsel interjections
Interrupting speakers
Marking exhibits
Obtaining proper spellings
Indicating non-verbal actions
Handling heated arguments, asides, and conversation by third parties
Handling adjournments Marking Exhibits
At pretrial proceedings, exhibits are marked by the reporter by affixing an exhibit stamp.  The exhibit stamp should be red in color and should be filled out by the reporter with a blue pen. This is to clearly distinguish a document marked as an exhibit from any copies that may later be made. You may use pre-made stickers instead of stamps if they fit on the document being marked To facilitate quick reference by counsel, placement of the exhibit stamp should be the top right corner of any document. If the top right corner is not available, place the stamp as close to the top of the document as possible. If there is no place on the entire face of the document to put the exhibit stamp, place the stamp on the back of the document. It is prudent practice to let counsel know that you are putting the exhibit stamp on the back of the document. Make sure when you are placing the stamp, that the stamp does not touch any written portion of the document.
When marking photographs, have prepared exhibit stamp stickers to place on the back of the photograph. The ink smudges when you stamp the back of photographs (with the shiny finish).  Stickers are often used for documents as well.
The reporter would include the following information in the exhibit stamp:
Sequential number (or letter if marked for identification)
Full name of witness (same as given when sworn in, all caps)
Date of examination
Reporter’s name and initials
Full exhibits receive a number designation ("D" for discovery):
