OR
“Pasted image 20240718000559.png” could not be found.Exhibits marked in a cross-examination on Affidavit do not have the letter "D":
“Pasted image 20240718000626.png” could not be found.Discussions off the Record
The reporter goes off the record only when both sides agree to go off the record If opposing counsel gives no response or any type of indication to the requesting counsel wanting to go off the record, the reporter can assume opposing counsel is fine with going off the record. The reporter should make it obvious that he or she is not writing anything that is being said.  Make an attempt to be obvious that you are off the record.
When counsel make the request to go off the record, it is recorded in the transcript unless the lawyer talks directly to the reporter only to go off the record; however, when the request is made to go back on the record, that is not included in the transcript.
When counsel are discussing whether or not to go off the record, that is included in the transcript.
Interrupting Speakers
Unlike clarifying the spelling of a word, you must make the interruption immediately to clarify something not heard or understood. If you hesitate, the speakers move on, and it is difficult to capture the moment again.
Say something short and to the point (“pardon me”) while making eye contact with the speaker. 
If you are clarifying a word that you think is the response but are not satisfied, repeat the response to the speaker.  For example: Did you say “yes”? If you didn’t hear an answer, don’t expect your audio to pick up the sound.
If you are unsure whether you heard a name or word correctly and can put that word into context later, make a notation and clarify the word during a break. If it's a proper name, you will have to get the spelling anyway.
Witnesses with accents can be difficult to understand, so be sure to advise examining counsel you are experiencing this difficulty.  Lawyers can then change the way they ask questions and will understand if you are interrupting often.
To clarify the spelling of a word, make a notation in your transcript. "Oops" is a good Case CAT feature for this! You can then ask your questions at the next break. A good resource for the spelling of proper nouns is from the documents themselves. Otherwise, you will direct your question to the witness or counsel to get a spelling. Record the information directly into your transcript or on your information page. 
The internet is a great resource for researching names of geographic areas, company names, street names, etc. 
It should be the goal of the reporter to clarify any information needed before they leave the discovery room. It will save time when editing.
You can try to tell a witness to slow down, but it often doesn't work. Do not interrupt if the lawyer is going for the "kill," the witness is reacting to the questions and not thinking, don't spoil the lawyer's train of thought or give the witness time to think.
Interjections
One of the biggest adjustments NAIT graduates have when they start out in industry is writing interjections by the witness's lawyer. One way to best deal with this scenario is to anticipate when an interjection or objection will be made.
Here is a list of possible reasons for an interjection or objection from opposing counsel:
Hypothetical questions. Examining counsel are not allowed to ask hypothetical questions, e.g., "If you weren't speeding, do you think the accident would have happened?"
Questions that ask for an opinion. Examining counsel are not allowed to ask for an opinion from the witness unless the witness is called as an expert in a specific field, e.g., "Do you think Mr. Jones did a good job in his position as manager?" gray area when it's about the witness's frame of mind
Questions that do not relate to the pleadings in a questioning for discovery or questions that do not fall within the “four corners” of an affidavit in a cross-examination on affidavit, e.g., if we had a car accident, and the witness was not claiming future loss of income because they got over their injuries after a certain amount of time, examining counsel cannot ask questions about their future employment and potential income
When examining counsel asks for an undertaking - lawyer will usually step in and answer for the witness
When the questioning becomes heated between the counsel and the witness, the witness’s lawyer may interject to protect his or her witness, i.e., they will make an objection just to stop the proceeding and give their witness's a chance to compose themselves again and think about their answers
The body language of the witness’s lawyer. Many times the witness’s lawyer will put his hand in front of witness or move up to the end of his chair so the witness knows not to answer the question and the lawyer can interject.
Note: In Canadian proceedings, witnesses do not answer questions that are objected to. You may see the witness answering in the demo videos from NCRA Career Launcher.Readbacks
Reporter readbacks must be performed proficiently upon request. Many times the competency of the reporter is judged by their ability to read back.
When asked to read back, take your time. Review your text or vertical notes prior to beginning the readback.
The readback should be in a loud, clear voice at a steady pace (approximately 140 wpm). You must give the speaker identification first, e.g., "Question: Where were you on the night in question? Answer: I was - Speaker: Ms. Smith: Don't answer that."
Readbacks should be read with back-up equipment on. If the readback is not the last question or answer, highlight or mark the spot that was read back, and copy and paste in the appropriate spot.
Sometimes the readback requested is not only the last question asked or answer given but is not specific. If necessary, ask clarifying questions to determine what is being requested to be read.
If you need a few minutes to find the portion to read back or would like to review it with the audio backup, ask for a brief adjournment.
Obtaining Spellings
To clarify the spelling of a word, make a notation in your steno notes or make a note on your information page. You can then get the spelling at the next break.
The best place to get spellings is from the documents themselves. Otherwise, depending on the spelling needed, you will have to ask the witness or possibly counsel to get a spelling. Once you receive the spelling, record the spelling directly into your transcript and/or in the top right-hand corner on the back of your information page. Some spellings, like geography and company names, can also be attained from the Internet.
In terms of spellings, it should be the goal of the reporter to attain all necessary spellings before he/she leaves the questioning room. As the reporter, you don't want to waste time when producing the transcript having to look things up.
Indicating Non-Verbal Actions
When a witness nods his head to indicate “yes” or shakes his head to indicate “no”, counsel may ask for a verbal response.  If they do not, you may indicate to counsel there was no verbal response.
If a witness uses a body motion to answer a question, counsel may describe the motion on the record or ask the witness to describe it.
Q Where did you hit your head?  (Witness points to his head)   (New Paragraph)
I notice you are indicating the left temple area; is that correct?
A Correct. 
If the lawyer doesn't do this, the reporter should interrupt and indicate there was no verbal response on the record.
We do not describe non-verbal actions in the record. There's no way to verify and it can be left to interpretation.
Heated Arguments
If there is a heated argument between counsel and the witness, do not interrupt and do the best you can.
If the heated argument is between counsel and their speech is overlapping, immediately step in and remind them to speak one at a time.
Conversation by Third Parties
If an observer/layperson speaks during a questioning and is not at the time under oath, immediately interject and ask whether the comments are to be included in the record.
If the comments are included in the record, the speaker is identified in colloquy format, e.g., MR. BROWN:
Handling Adjournments
Similar to discussions off the record, all counsel must agree to adjourn.
Like discussions off the record, the reporter quits writing when both sides agree to adjourn.
Apply Professional Conduct During Proceedings
You should provide professional conduct from the time you leave your home until you get back. How you act and present yourself during discussions off the record, adjournments, and in setting up and dismantling your equipment is just as important as when you write the proceeding. Ask counsel if they would like to order a transcript
Check for delivery deadlines Regular (5-10 business days)
Expedited (3-5 business days)
Next day Counsel may sometimes put a transcript order on hold. This means they don't want it produced right away but may order a copy in the future. Questionings in Aid Upload backup digital files to your computer

Be personable and polite

6-the-business/16-continuations.html.title: Continuations
6-the-business/16-continuations.html.description:
Questioning transcripts are witness-based, i.e., each witness's transcript is a discrete document. E.g., if you take the questioning of 3 witnesses in one day, each witness's transcript will begin with page 1, exhibit 1, and undertaking 1 Court trials/quasi-judicial trials are case-based, i.e., proceedings are continuous and don't start over for each individual witness Transcript page numbers & exhibit numbers carry on throughout the whole proceeding Generally speaking, an examining lawyer only gets one chance to examine a witness from the other side during the questioning for discovery stage. However, sometimes a witness is examined at a discovery, and the examining lawyer will not finish his or her questioning or will have finished questioning subject to the undertakings that were given or new documents that may be produced into evidence before trial. When the lawyer comes back to question the witness a second time on a different date, this is called a continuation.
Why might a questioning be continued? adjourned (to a specified date) or adjourned sine die (to a date in the future)
adjourned subject to the undertakings (very specific adjournment where further questioning may only apply to the undertakings)
reopen a concluded questioning (because new documents were filed or new information has come to light) At the time the booking is made, the reporting firm will generally ask if it is a continuation so the reporter knows before they attend the discovery.
How else might a reporter know it's a continuation? Multiday bookings
Firm may advise the proceedings are continued
Counsel may advise the proceedings are continued
Reporter may inquire whether the proceedings are continued When a reporter is reporting a continuation of a questioning for discovery, they will request the last page number, the last exhibit number, and the last undertaking number from the previous examination. Paragraph numbers are not applied in Alberta transcripts, but you may encounter them in other jurisdictions (also witness-based and continued on further questioning dates) The cover page will then read "Continued Questioning for Discovery of ^Witness's Name^"
The reporter at a continuation may ask examining counsel if they would like the witness resworn.  The sworn notation may then read:
^WITNESS'S NAME^, Sworn, Questioned by ^Lawyer's Name^
^WITNESS'S NAME^, Previously Sworn, Questioned by ^Lawyer's Name^

6-the-business/17-american-depositions.h.title: American Depositions
6-the-business/17-american-depositions.h.description:
You may find an American lawsuit where one of the witnesses lives in Canada and, as a result, they conduct the deposition here.Formatting and Title Page
Most firms in Canada will use their regular discovery format.
The style of cause is different in American depositions and will be transposed on the title page in a similar format as that given to them. The rest of the title page will remain the same.
Major Differences Between Questionings and Depositions
In most cases, the transcript is first sent to the witness with a covering letter.
The witness can make any changes to the transcripts it wants to. To do this, the witness will fill out an errata sheet attached to the back of the transcript. The errata sheet will contain (1) the page and line number of each change, (2) the actual change itself, (3) the reason for the change, (4) signature by witness certifying that the deposition is correct as stated with the exceptions noted above, and (5) the date that the errata sheet was filled out.
In administering the oath, the witness raises his right hand, no Bible, no standing. The witness is sworn, not affirmed.
Exhibits marked in the deposition are attached to the back of the transcript and become part of the actual transcript.
The certificate filled out by the reporter is much more in depth.
Having a videographer present in a deposition is much more common that in questionings in Canada.
In most depositions if the witness's counsel makes an objection to a question, the witness still answers the question after the objection has been made. In Canada, the witness will not answer and the examining lawyer will have to go to Chambers and receive a ruling in his favor to get the witness to answer.
American lawyers, when they conduct a deposition in Canada, almost always pay in American dollars.

6-the-business/21-quasi-judicial-hearing.title: Quasi-Judicial Hearings
6-the-business/21-quasi-judicial-hearing.description:
Characteristics:
Impartiality: The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) or panel must act impartially and without bias.
Due Process: Parties are entitled to due process, including the right to present evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and receive a fair hearing.
Record-Keeping: A detailed record of the proceedings is maintained for transparency and review purposes.
Expertise: The decision-makers are often experts in the relevant field, allowing for informed and specialized judgments.
Quasi-judicial hearings blend elements of formal judicial procedures with the practicalities and expertise of administrative bodies, ensuring that disputes and regulatory matters are resolved fairly and efficiently within their specific contexts.The quasi-judicial hearing process involves administrative agencies or bodies that perform functions similar to those of a court, but within the context of their specific areas of expertise. These hearings are often related to regulatory, administrative, or disciplinary actions. Here is an overview of the quasi-judicial hearing process:
Complaint/Petition: The process begins with the filing of a complaint, petition, or application by an individual, organization, or government entity. This initiates the case and sets the procedural wheels in motion.
Notice of Hearing: The parties involved are notified about the hearing. This notice includes the date, time, place, and nature of the hearing, ensuring that all parties have adequate time to prepare. Preliminary Conference: Sometimes, a preliminary conference is held to clarify issues, set timelines, and discuss procedural matters.
Discovery: Similar to judicial proceedings, parties may engage in discovery to gather evidence and information from each other. Administrative Law Judge (ALJ): The hearing is typically presided over by an Administrative Law Judge or a panel. The ALJ or panel acts as an impartial arbiter.
Opening Statements: Both parties may present opening statements to outline their positions and the evidence they intend to present.
Presentation of Evidence: Evidence is presented by both sides. This includes witness testimonies, documents, and other relevant materials. Witnesses may be cross-examined by the opposing party.
Rules of Evidence: While formal rules of evidence may be relaxed compared to judicial proceedings, the ALJ ensures that evidence presented is relevant and reliable.
Record of Proceedings: The entire hearing is typically recorded and transcribed to ensure there is an accurate record for review. Briefs and Arguments: Parties may be allowed to submit post-hearing briefs or written arguments summarizing their positions and the evidence presented.
Deliberation and Decision: The ALJ or panel reviews the evidence and arguments, deliberates, and makes a decision based on the merits of the case.
Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law: The decision includes findings of fact and conclusions of law, detailing the reasoning behind the decision.
Issuance of Decision: The decision is issued in writing and provided to all parties involved. This document outlines the outcome and any orders or sanctions imposed. Internal Appeals: There may be an internal appeals process within the agency or body, where the decision can be reviewed by a higher authority within the same organization.
Judicial Review: Parties dissatisfied with the decision may seek judicial review in a court of law. The court reviews the administrative record and determines whether the quasi-judicial body acted within its authority and followed proper procedures. Implementation of Decision: The decision is enforced as per the agency's or body's rules. This may involve sanctions, penalties, or other actions as prescribed in the decision.
Compliance Monitoring: The agency may monitor compliance with the decision and take further action if necessary.

index.html.description: Welcome! StenoTab is a compilation of all my notes from NAIT's Captioning and Court Reporting program. I created this site for 3 reasons: 1. I strongly believe that knowledge should be free and accessible to everyone 2. I want to help foster a community where the success of one is the success of all 3. I hope to inspire people to explore the field, whether as a potential career or to appreciate its important role in the legal system and our lives, in generalStenography 1: the art or process of writing in shorthand 2: shorthand especially written from dictation or oral discourse 3: the making of shorthand notes and subsequent transcription of them Merriam-Webster.com Captioners and court reporters are professionals who can type at speeds of 225 words per minute or more with at least 95% accuracy using a steno machine. We turn spoken words into written text using our machine and computer technology.Being a captioner or court reporter is a unique and exciting career. Every day is different, and you get to learn new and interesting things all the time. Plus, it has the potential to be quite lucrative. Career opportunities include: Broadcast Captioner (live television events and internet programs) CART Provider (real-time transcription in educational, corporate, or community settings) Court Reporter (court trials, examinations for discovery, and hearings) But there’s a lot to learn beyond just typing well!Are we being replaced by AI? Short answer: No. Long answer: I don't believe it will be possible to replace court reporters with AI, and this belief stems from two main factors: human cognition and accountability. Human cognition is essential to what we do. Court reporters manage fast speech, accents, crosstalk, mumbling, and background noise in real-time and can ask for clarification on ambiguous terms. We can interrupt the proceedings to ascertain what the speaker said if we missed it. "Fifteen" can sound like "fifty," just as "B" can sound like "V." Plus, homophones exist – for example, did the speaker say "write" or "right"? Context plays a vital role too. Did the officer say "No. Shots were fired," or did he say "No shots were fired"? A court reporter can hear the distinction; AI can't. And what error rate would you or your client be okay with? 10%? 20%? Hiring a certified court reporter guarantees a near perfect transcript. Additionally, AI datasets have shown significant racial biases. Court reporters ensure the accuracy of the record as impartial third parties. We certify transcripts and are legally responsible for errors. In other words, we display unbiased accountability. Who would be accountable if AI takes down the record incorrectly? The party providing the AI, the company that owns it, or the legal system? Many US courtrooms have already banned AI entirely, and I believe this issue was a major factor in those decisions. The other concern is privacy. One of the 12 major risks to the use of AI is insecurity. There have been multiple occasions when faulty data storage practices resulted in leaked personal data. AI simply cannot be incorporated into a legal setting in its current state. Plus, if AI has advanced to the point of replacing humans, I think it’s safe to say that we won’t be the only profession affected. What is digital reporting? A digital reporter operates an audio recording device to capture what happens during a proceeding. The make minimal "tag notes" to identify speakers and highlight key moments, but their only record is the audio file itself. They don't take down a complete word-for-word account of everything said and don't use stenography. If the equipment fails due to technical issues or user error, there's no backup. This could seriously harm a case. Once the recording is made, the digital reporter’s job is essentially done. They aren’t responsible for creating the final transcript. Instead, the audio is broken up into smaller clips and sent to transcriptionists, often located in other countries. These transcriptionists listen to the clips and type out what they hear, and then the agency assembles the final transcript. The digital reporter often doesn’t review the final transcript or the recording, yet may still falsely certify it as accurate. As you can probably imagine, there are major problems with this process. Since they're relying on recordings, the final transcript is often full of errors or missing sections. One attorney in California, Melissa B. Buchman, submitted a piece to the Los Angeles & San Francisco Daily Journal about an experience she had with a digital reporter where 55 pages (an entire hour of testimony) was completely left out of the final transcript. Another issue is that digital reporters don’t handle the security of sensitive information like names, addresses, or birth dates. If there’s a data breach, personal details could be exposed, increasing the risk of identity theft. The way transcripts are shared and stored makes it harder to protect that information. With digital reporting, there’s just no guarantee of accuracy or confidentiality, leaving room for mistakes and potential security risks. If you're looking into schooling for court reporting, my recommendation is to make sure it's not digital reporting. Why not record everything? Recording still needs transcription, which is less efficient and secure. Multiple transcriptionists are needed to match the output of one stenographer, increasing errors and confidentiality risks. Recording alone is outdated. Is there a shortage of court reporters? I'll only speak to the situation here in Alberta, but I believe this issue is common in many parts of Canada and the US. In September 2023, Court of King’s Bench Chief Justice Mary Moreau issued a memo about the use of court reporters in legal proceedings. The memo mentioned a shortage of reporters, which didn’t accurately reflect the situation. ASRA President Di Rocco pointed out that Alberta has 145 certified reporters, a number that’s stable and growing thanks to training programs like NAIT’s. Since these concerns were raised, no trials have gone uncovered, and ASRA was able to bring their issues directly to the Chief of Staff for the Minister of Justice in 2024. Despite this, some argue that court reporters aren’t needed and off-site transcription is good enough. Shawn King, vice-president of the Criminal Trial Lawyers’ Association, shared this view but acknowledged that off-site transcriptions aren’t always accurate. This is especially true when dealing with unclear audio or background noise, issues an on-site reporter can address in real-time. But here’s the key question: How many errors would you be comfortable with in a transcript? What if it’s a case that directly affects you? What if it’s a serious crime, like a murder or sexual assault case? Would you be okay with a 10% or 20% error rate? At what point do you see the value of having a court reporter in the courtroom? So to answer the question: No, there is not a shortage of court reporters. But the future of the profession is a real and ongoing concern. How do I get into steno? Where do I start? If you're thinking about a career in steno, you can try out NCRA’s A to Z program (aka Discover Steno, which is also offered by NAIT) for free. It’s a great way to get an introduction to stenography. The program also connects you with experienced court reporters and captioners, so you can ask questions about the field. By the end, you'll have a good understanding of the basics and how to start working toward certification. I took the program myself and highly recommend it; it’s a fantastic way to learn more before committing to a captioning/court reporting program. If you have any questions or want to connect, feel free to send me an email
